# The Habit of Truth

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I can still my racing thoughts and hear your whispered tone,
If I can silence all the noise that drowns your voice anew,
And recognize your presence when I feel most alone.

How often have I turned away when you approached my door?
How frequently I've plugged my ears when comfort was my need?
I chose the sweeter falsehoods that I wanted to explore,
Rejecting harder wisdom that might make my spirit bleed.

Yet truth, you never left me, though I wandered far astray,
You waited with such patience as I chased my grand delusions.
You stood beside me silently through night and troubled day,
As I embraced my carefully constructed illusions.

Now I am learning slowly how to cultivate your sound,
To recognize your cadence in the chaos of my mind.
The habit of your listening makes my footing more profound,
And speaking you becomes the greatest freedom I can find.

So truth, I pledge to listen, though your words may bring me pain,
To honor what you tell me, though it shatters what I know.
For in your stark revealing, I find purpose once again,
And in your honest presence, I find space in which to grow.

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,

How often I've drowned you with my noise,

With judgments hardened by fear and pride,

Truth! I shall speak you when I've earned the right,

# Ember Soul

This anger burns deep within,
A smoldering coal beneath my skin,
Fed by memories of what has been,
And paths I cannot walk again.

It flickers in the hollow night,
When silence amplifies its might,
A companion both wrong and right,
My shadow cast in crimson light.

I've tried to douse these flames with tears,
To quench the heat collected years,
But water turns to steam and clears,
Revealing what my heart most fears.

Has become where my spirit hides.

I'll learn to channel what before
I thought would only burn and score
The landscape of my soul's core.

This anger burns deep within,
But maybe now it's time to begin
To see this fire as discipline,
A power neither loss nor sin.

# The Fire Within

This anger burns deep within,
A flame that never seems to dim.
It flickers through my hollow bones,
And whispers ancient, bitter tones.

I've carried it through countless days,
This smoldering coal that never grays.
It warms me when the world turns cold,
A secret that refuses to grow old.

Sometimes it's just a gentle heat,
A low reminder, soft and sweet.
But often it becomes a blaze
That blinds my eyes and fills my gaze.

I've tried to douse it with forgiveness,
To flood its chambers with completeness.
Yet somehow embers always stay,
Refusing simply to fade away.

Perhaps this fire serves a purpose,
Beyond the pain that lies beneath the surface.
It forges strength from broken parts,
And melts the ice around closed hearts.

This anger burns deep within me still,
A force I've learned to wield with skill.
Not just destruction in its wake,
But power to bend instead of break.

So I will keep this sacred flame,
Not as my burden or my shame,
But as the light that guides me through
To something stronger, something true.

This Anger Burns Deep Within

This anger burns deep within,
A smoldering coal beneath my skin.
It whispers through my veins at night,
A restless, pulsing, crimson light.

I carry it through crowded streets,
Past strangers' smiles and casual greets.
They cannot see the flames that rise
Behind the curtain of my eyes.

It started as a tiny spark,
A fleeting moment in the dark.
But fed by silence and by pain,
It grew when I could not explain.

The weight of words I never said,
The battles fought inside my head,
The injustice that I've witnessed grow—
These are the winds that make it glow.

Sometimes I fear what it might do
If given air and passage through
The careful walls I've built with time
To keep contained this fire of mine.

Yet in this burn, I find my strength,
A force that pushes me at length
To stand against what isn't right,
To use this flame to bring the light.

This anger burns deep within me still,
Not as destroyer, but to fulfill
A purpose greater than my rage:
To write my truth upon the page.

This anger burns deep within,

Born from wounds I cannot name,
Nursed by sorrow, fed by shame.
It coils around my beating heart,
A serpent skilled in venom's art.

I've tried to drown it, cold and deep,
In oceans of enforced sleep.
I've tried to starve it, day by day,
Yet still it finds its stubborn way.

This anger burns deep within,
A legacy of what has been.

That time refuses to wash away.

Sometimes it flares in sudden rage,
A captive beast that breaks its cage.
Sometimes it simmers, low and slow,
A patient predator, crouched low.

I wonder if this fire I bear
Is mine alone, or one we share?
Do others feel this molten core,
This heat that burns forevermore?

Perhaps this flame that scalds my soul
Serves purpose I cannot control.

I'd lose my way in endless night.

This anger burns deep within,
Both enemy and closest kin.
I learn to hold it, not destroy,
To use its heat but not employ

This anger burns deep within,
A molten core beneath my skin.
It simmers in the hollow space
Where reason once had found its place.

Each slight, each wound, each careless word
Adds fuel to what's now occurred—
A raging fire that will not cease,
That steals away my inner peace.

I've tried to douse these flames with tears,
To quench the heat of bygone years.
But water turns to steam on touch,
The temperature has grown too much.

Sometimes I wonder if this rage
Is heritage, a sacred wage
Passed down through generations' blood,
A necessary shield from flood.

Perhaps this burning is a gift,
A force that causes me to lift
My voice against injustice's reign,
To push through walls of needless pain.

Or maybe it's a poison slow,
Destroying what I love and know,
Consuming beauty, joy, and light,
Leaving only ashen night.

This anger burns deep within me,
Both jailer and the prison key.
I must decide which role to choose—
What parts to keep, what parts to lose.

For fire destroys, but also clears
The ground for what next appears.
From blackened earth, new growth begins—
When anger burns deep within.

War's a joke for me and you,
While distant bombs light up the sky,
We sit in comfort, sipping brew,
As others fight and others die.

We speak of conflict with such ease,
Debating tactics from afar,
Our opinions float like autumn leaves,
While soldiers drown in blood and tar.

War's a joke until it's not,
Until it reaches your front door,
Until the battles being fought
Are happening on your own shore.

War's a joke on television screens,
In history books and grand parades,
But ask the child who intervenes
Between her mother and the raids.

Ask the medic holding parts
Of someone who was whole before,
Ask the lovers torn apart,
If they still find humor in this war.

War's a joke for me and you,
Because we've never heard the sound
Of bullets tearing bodies through
Or felt the trembling of the ground.

War's a joke we shouldn't tell,
A punchline lost in tears and pain,
For those who've lived through living hell
Find nothing funny to explain.

So let us pause before we speak
Of conflict with such careless mirth,
For war leaves nations worn and weak,
And scars the face of mother earth.

# The Joke of War

War's a joke for me and you,
While others bleed and others die.
We sit in comfort, sipping brew,
As missiles streak across the sky.

We speak of conflict like a game,
With strategy and winning moves.
Detached from bodies torn and maimed,
From children's graves in ordered rows.

The generals plot with plastic pins,
On maps that show no human pain.
They count the losses, count the wins,
While mothers search through mud and rain.

War's a joke when viewed from far,
Through screens that sanitize the gore.
We change the channel, raise the bar,
And talk of glory, talk of lore.

But stand among the rubble heap,
Where hospitals once stood with pride.
The joke falls flat, we cannot sleep,
With ghosts of truth we cannot hide.

War's a joke for me and you,
Until it knocks upon our door.
Until our loved ones bid adieu,
And join the ranks of nevermore.

So laugh, my friend, while still you can,
At this dark comedy we've made.
But know the punchline's final plan
Is that we all will be betrayed.

# Litany of Fears

My God, how many are my fears!
They multiply like shadows cast
By setting suns on weathered walls,
Stretching longer as day falls past.

I fear the silence of the night,
The empty spaces in between
The words we speak but never mean,
And truths too terrible to glean.

I fear the future's misty veil,
The paths untaken, chances lost,
The winter of abandoned dreams
Preserved in memory's bitter frost.

I fear the judgment in your eyes,
The slow withdrawal of your hand,
The gradual fading of your voice
Like footprints washing from the sand.

I fear my own capacity
For blindness to another's pain,
For selfishness, for cruelty,
For sins committed not in vain.

I fear the world's indifference,
The casual violence of our days,
The children crying in the dark,
The God who turns His face away.

My fears, like stars, cannot be counted—
Each one burning bright and clear.
Yet in their vastness lies my comfort:
I am not alone in fear.

# Trepidations

My God, how many are my fears!
They multiply like autumn leaves,
Swirling in the bitter breeze
That whistles through my sleepless years.

Each morning brings fresh anxieties,
Shadows lurking at the edge of light.
They follow me from day to night,
Persistent as the rolling seas.

I fear the future's hidden face,
The past's long-buried memories,
The present's fragile certainties,
Time's relentless, crushing pace.

I fear the words I've left unsaid,
The bridges burned, the paths untried,
The love withheld through foolish pride,
The dreams abandoned in my head.

I fear the stranger's judging gaze,
The silence after speaking true,
The emptiness when hope falls through,
The meaningless of passing days.

Yet in this storm of dread and doubt,
A quiet voice reminds me still:
Fear cannot break the stubborn will
That dares to seek a way about.

Perhaps my fears, so vast in scope,
Are but the shadow side of care—
For what we love, we fear to spare,
And what we dread defines our hope.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'He looks at me with a madman's eyes -'

He looks at me with a madman's eyes -
Wild, unfettered, burning bright,
Pupils dilated in the half-light,
Windows to a mind untethered from our world.

I see galaxies spinning in their depths,
Constellations no astronomer has mapped,
Truths that science cannot capture,
Visions that dance beyond reason's grasp.

What does he perceive when he looks at me?
Am I monster or savior in his sight?
Perhaps I'm merely a canvas
For his mind to paint its chaos upon.

His gaze holds me, transfixed,
Like a specimen pinned for study.
The intensity makes me wonder
If madness might be contagious.

Behind those eyes lies a universe
With different laws of physics,
Where time bends and logic shatters,
Where nightmares and dreams coexist.

I find myself leaning closer,
Drawn to the abyss of his stare,
Curious what wisdom hides
In the fragments of his fractured mind.

Perhaps there's truth in madness,
Clarity in delusion's embrace.
Perhaps his eyes see clearly
What sanity has taught us to ignore.

Solitude

In the quiet corners of my mind,
I find myself alone with thoughts unkind.
Shadows stretch across an empty room,
As daylight fades into approaching gloom.

Footsteps echo on the hardwood floor,
No one waits behind the closed front door.
The kettle whistles—tea for only one,
Another day of solitude begun.

I watch the couples walking hand in hand,
Their laughter floating like grains of sand
That slip between my fingers as I try
To hold onto connections that have gone by.

The phone sits silent on the kitchen shelf,
My voice grows rusty, talking to myself.
The calendar holds blank squares, stark and white,
No plans to break the sameness of each night.

Yet in this loneliness, I slowly find
A different kind of peace within my mind.
The silence offers space for thoughts to grow,
A canvas where my truest self can show.

Perhaps this solitude is not a cage,
But rather just another turning page.
In learning how to be my own best friend,
I find a strength on which I can depend.

For lonely doesn't mean that I am lost,
Just traveling solo, whatever the cost.
In quiet moments, when the world grows still,
I find the courage to climb my own hill.

In the hollow of my chest

all other voices quelled.

a ghost among the living,

hellos without the giving.

The morning light spills through
my window's dusty pane,
illuminating rooms
where memories remain.

My shadow stretches long
across the kitchen floor,
companion to the song
of kettles, nothing more.

At night the ceiling holds
my whispered conversations,
returns them hundredfold
in mocking iterations.

The phone sits undisturbed,
a monument to stillness,
its purpose now disturbed
by technological illness.

I've learned to set two plates
from habit, nothing less,
then clear away the space
with practiced emptiness.

The world outside moves on
in pairs and groups and masses.
I watch them from beyond
the veil that loneliness casts.

Yet in this solitude
I've found a certain peace,
a quiet interlude
where expectations cease.

For lonely isn't empty
when filled with one's own grace—
perhaps the heart has plenty
when given proper space.

# Echoes of the Outback

On a lonely selection far out in the West,

The windmill creaks slowly, drawing life from below,

Teaching lessons of patience as old as they're true.

On this lonely selection, I've found who I am,

On a lonely selection far out in the West,

The stars are his ceiling, the dirt is his floor,

On this lonely selection far out in the West.

To this land that both breaks and sustains me,

For a dream that's now withered and old.

Yet still there is beauty in morning's first light,
As it creeps o'er the vast open space,

In this God-forsaken place.

Of dreams beyond their reach.

There are those who fear abandonment,
The severing of ties,
And those who fear commitment,
What binds them compromised.

Some fear the world's indifference,

This burden of our humanness,

Perhaps in sharing what we dread,

Their power to cause us pain.

Everyone has a fear,

With trembling openness.

# Divine Solace

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My refuge when the storms descend,
The lighthouse when my path is dim,
The voice that calls me home again.

When morning breaks across the hills,
I seek Thy face with earnest heart.
In deserts parched, in valleys low,
I thirst for Thee, my counterpart.

No earthly pleasure satisfies
The soul that knows Thy tender grace.
No human love, however sweet,
Can fill Thy sacred dwelling place.

When shadows lengthen with the day
And darkness threatens to consume,

That scatters fear and conquers gloom.

In silence deep, I hear Thy call,
A whisper softer than the breeze,
Yet stronger than the ocean's roar,
More constant than the ancient trees.

My hands I lift in reverent praise,
My spirit soars on wings of prayer.
The world may offer fleeting joys,
But only Thou art always there.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
When all else fades and falls away,
Thy love remains my cornerstone,
My strength, my song, my hope, my stay.

My refuge when storms rage and moan,
My shelter from life's ceaseless rain,
My balm for every throbbing pain.

When darkness shrouds my weary soul,
When broken pieces need be whole,
I turn my face toward Thy light,
That pierces through my endless night.

In meadows green or deserts bare,
I sense Thy presence everywhere.
The whispered breeze, the mountain tall,
Each testifies—Thou mad'st them all.

What need have I for worldly fame?
What comfort in an empty name?
All treasures pale, all glories fade;
In Thee alone, my hope is laid.

When friends depart and loved ones leave,
When joy surrenders unto grief,
Thy steadfast love remains unmoved,
Thy covenant daily proved.

Before the stars were hung in space,
Before time began its race,
Thy thoughts toward me were set in love,
Planned from Thy throne in heaven above.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My heart is Thine, my cornerstone.
Through life, through death, through endless days,
My soul shall sing Thy endless praise.

# Metamorphosis

I was a grovelling creature once,
Belly pressed against cold earth,
Eating dust and tasting shame,
Unaware of my own worth.

My spine curved in permanent bow,
Eyes trained downward, never up,
Fingers clutching at the dirt,
Lips pressed to a bitter cup.

I learned to live within the dark,
To shrink myself, to disappear,
To speak in whispers, if at all,
To nurture nothing but my fear.

The sky existed as a myth,
A story told by standing men,
While I remained beneath their feet,
Counting seconds in my den.

But metamorphosis begins
In secret places, out of sight.
My bones grew restless in their cage,
My soul developed appetite.

One morning, something in me broke—
Or perhaps it finally mended.
I placed one palm against the ground
And pushed until my bowing ended.

Vertebrae by vertebrae,
I claimed the column of my spine.
Straightened shoulders, lifted chin,
Reclaimed what always had been mine.

Now I stand in golden light,
Face turned skyward, breathing deep.
The grovelling creature shed its skin;
That hollow shell is mine to keep—

A reminder of the strength it took
To rise from dust and stand up tall,
To recognize the truth at last:
I never should have crawled at all.

People Are Happy

People are happy when the morning breaks,
As sunlight filters through half-drawn blinds,
When coffee brews and the whole house wakes
To possibilities of countless kinds.

People are happy in quiet moments shared,
A knowing glance across a crowded room,
In whispered secrets that show someone cared
Enough to listen when wrapped in gloom.

People are happy with sand between their toes,
With raindrops racing down windowpanes,
In gardens where the stubborn wildflower grows,
And unexpected laughter after pains.

People are happy around tables filled with food,
Where stories flow like rivers to the sea,
Where generations gather in grateful mood,
Connecting past to what's yet to be.

People are happy when holding someone's hand,
When stars appear in twilight's purple haze,
When music moves them in ways they understand
But cannot quite explain in simple phrase.

People are happy in the struggle and the strife,
Finding purpose in the challenges they meet,
For happiness isn't just the absence of all grief,
But finding sweetness where bitter meets sweet.

People are happy not because life is perfect,
But because they've learned to see the light
That filters through the cracks of the imperfect,
Illuminating beauty in the ordinary sight.

It seems like light years ago

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a river proudly flowed,
Mirrors of sky now cracked with pain,
Holding memories the land once showed.

Parched earth cradles these final tears,
Thirsty cracks reach toward each edge,
Drinking slowly through the years
What water clings to this final ledge.

Fish that swam in currents strong
Now circle tightly, trapped in space,
Their silver bodies—a vanishing throng—
Flash desperate in their shrinking place.

Herons that waded deep and free
Now bend their necks to shallow bowls,
Their patient hunting, a legacy
Of adaptation as nature rolls.

The sun beats down with merciless glare,
Evaporating hope day by day,
While clouds drift by without a care,
Carrying promised rain away.

I trace my finger through cooling mud,
Remember when I couldn't see the shore,
When these banks contained a flood,
When abundance seemed forevermore.

Just a few dwindling pools remain—
Testament to what we failed to keep,
A landscape altered, a subtle pain,
As the land around us falls asleep.

Perhaps tomorrow clouds will break,
Perhaps the sky will remember how
To fill these hollows, a thirst to slake,
And begin again what ends now.

The Gift of Loss

Loss can be good for us, though at first we break,
Like winter stripping trees of summer's pride,
Revealing strength in branches as they shake,
And teaching us what truly lives inside.

The empty spaces carved by what has gone
Create new rooms where light can filter through.
The tears we shed become the dew at dawn,
Nourishing soil where something fresh may grow.

We learn to value what remains more dear,
To notice beauty in the smallest things.
The bird's song sounds more precious to the ear
When we have known the silence absence brings.

Our hands, once clutching tightly what we loved,
Now open wide to catch what comes our way.
The heart that breaks is not beyond repair—
It mends with gold in cracks where light can play.

Loss teaches patience in the darkest hours,
Resilience when we think we cannot stand.
It shows us depths of strength we never knew,
Like hidden water beneath desert sand.

So when the weight of absence bends you low,
Remember how the empty nest still sings,
How fallen leaves make rich the soil below,
How endings often birth beginnings.

Making way for something more alive.

I've lost my way and found a better path,
Lost arguments and gained humility,
Lost love and learned to love myself instead,
Lost certainty and found serenity.

The things we clutch most tightly cause us pain,
Our knuckles white with fear of letting go.
But open palms receive what closed hands can't—
New gifts that only empty hands can know.

Loss teaches us the art of starting fresh,
Of building something different from before.
The house that crumbles makes room for the new;
What falls away reveals another door.

So when the tide recedes and takes away
The castles that you built upon the sand,
Remember that the beach is cleared for you
To build again with wiser heart and hand.

Loss can be good for us, this much is true,
Though grief may be the price we have to pay
For learning what remains when all else fades:
The strength to face another day.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Loss can be good for us,'

instance_metrics.response:
The Gift of Loss

Loss can be good for us,
Though at first we rarely see
How emptiness might nurture growth
Or absence set us free.

The hollowed heart creates a space
Where something new can bloom.
The shattered plans make way for paths
We never would assume.

When cherished things are taken away,
Our grip on life relaxes.
We learn that we can still survive
Despite what fate exacts.

The job that vanished taught us strength,
The love that left taught worth.
The dream deferred revealed new hopes
We hadn't given birth.

Loss strips away our certainties,
Our comfortable disguise.
It forces us to reimagine
What we most prize.

In losing, we discover parts
Of ourselves long concealed.
In absence, presence takes new form,
Our essence is revealed.

So when the darkness closes in
And what you love departs,
Remember that the empty space
Makes room for fresh starts.

Loss can be good for us,
Not as suffering for its sake,
But as the necessary void
From which new life awakes.

Beneath your overwhelming blaze.

To keep our fragile planet whole.

So shine on, fool, unruly Sun,

The dance of life you've long begun
Continues at your blazing speed.

# Country Bride

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
With cheeks like apples, bright and fair,
She dances through the fields of hay,
The morning sunlight in her hair.

Her laughter rings across the land,
As clear as church bells on the hill.
With calloused palms and gentle hand,
She tends the earth with loving skill.

At dawn she rises with the sun,
To milk the cows and feed the hens.
A thousand chores are never done,
Yet still she smiles as day descends.

Her husband watches from afar,
This woman who has claimed his heart.
More radiant than the evening star,
She is his end and his new start.

Together they have planted seeds
Of wheat and corn and family.
She gives him everything he needs—
Love rooted in simplicity.

When autumn winds bring golden leaves,
And summer's warmth begins to wane,
She gathers what the season gives,
Preparing for the winter's reign.

A farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Her spirit free as birds in flight.
The keeper of their dreams by day,
The warmth within his arms at night.

Rises before the break of day.
Her hands are strong, her spirit bright,
As morning chases away the night.

She tends the garden's fertile rows,

The chickens cluck around her feet,

When winter comes with frost and snow,

Her needles click a soothing song,
As outside, nights grow dark and long.

In springtime, when the world turns new,
She plants her hopes and dreams anew.
The farmer's wife, both young and gay,
Embraces life from day to day.

God is the Refuge of His Saints

God is the refuge of His saints,
When storms of darkness fall;
A fortress strong that never faints,
A shelter for us all.

Though thunders roar and tempests rage,
Though mountains shake and seas arise,
He stands unmoved from age to age,
His promise never dies.

Beneath the shadow of His wings,
We find our perfect peace;
While every troubled spirit sings
Of grace that brings release.

When sorrows like a bitter flood
Threaten to overwhelm the soul,
We stand protected by His blood,
His mercy makes us whole.

What enemy can harm the heart
That rests in His embrace?
What power can tear His love apart
Or steal away His grace?

Through valleys deep and deserts wide,
Through fire and flood and pain,
He walks beside us as our guide,
Our hope is not in vain.

When earthly comforts fade away
And human strength departs,
His presence is our strength and stay,
The anchor for our hearts.

God is the refuge of His saints,
A haven ever near;
Though all else fails and courage faints,
We need not doubt or fear.

# Divine Shelter

God is the refuge of his saints,
A fortress standing through the years,
Where weary souls find sweet release
And trembling hearts lay down their fears.

When tempests rage and shadows fall,
When sorrow's tide threatens to drown,
His mighty arms encircle all
Who seek His face when troubles frown.

The world may shake with violence,
And nations rage with bitter strife,
Yet in His presence there remains
A sacred peace transcending life.

No weapon formed against His own
Shall ultimately bring them harm;
The Shepherd watches o'er His sheep
With loving eye and steady arm.

Through valleys dark and mountains steep,
Through deserts parched and forests wild,
The Father guides with gentle hand
Each stumbling, faith-filled, trusting child.

When strength has failed and hope grows dim,
When prayers seem lost in empty air,
The refuge stands, unchanging still—
His love the answer to each prayer.

So let the storms of life descend,
Let troubles come as troubles will;
God is the refuge of his saints,
Their ever-present shelter still.

instance_metrics.response:
God is the Refuge of His Saints

God is the refuge of His saints,
When storms of sharp distress invade;
Ere we can offer our complaints,
Behold Him present with His aid.

Let mountains from their seats be hurled
Down to the deep, and buried there,
Convulsions shake the solid world—
Our faith shall never yield to fear.

Loud may the troubled ocean roar;
In sacred peace our souls abide;
While every nation, every shore,
Trembles and dreads the swelling tide.

There is a stream whose gentle flow
Supplies the city of our God,
Life, love, and joy, still gliding through,
And watering our divine abode.

That sacred stream, Thine holy word,
Our grief allays, our fear controls;
Sweet peace Thy promises afford,
And give new strength to fainting souls.

Zion enjoys her Monarch's love,
Secure against a threatening hour;
Nor can her firm foundation move,
Built on His truth, and armed with power.

When darkness seems to hide His face,
We rest on His unchanging grace;
In every high and stormy gale,
Our anchor holds within the veil.

# Sanctuary

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the quiet corners,
Where shadows offer solace and the world
Cannot intrude with its demanding voice.

She seeks the gentle refuge of absence,
A temporary vanishing from sight,
Not from fear or shame or weakness,
But from the exhaustion of being seen.

In these moments of self-concealment,
She becomes the whisper in the leaves,
The space between heartbeats,
The pause before the rain begins to fall.

Her disappearance is not an ending
But a necessary gathering of strength,
A sacred ritual of self-preservation
When the world has taken more than she can give.

For in hiding, she remembers herself,
Reclaims the pieces scattered by expectation,
Reweaves the fraying edges of her soul
Into something whole and solely hers again.

And when she emerges from her shelter,
She carries with her the power of retreat,
The wisdom learned in silent communion
With the deepest currents of her being.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in that wanting lies a profound truth:
That to withdraw is not to surrender,
But to honor the sacred rhythm of becoming.

Not tolerance merely, but celebration

In honoring your journey as I walk my own,

# The Silent Muse

A poet loses his power for poetry
Like a river running dry in summer heat,
Words once flowing free now trapped inside,
Echoes of verses he cannot complete.

The blank page mocks with pristine white,
Where stanzas used to dance and leap.
His pen hovers, trembling with doubt,
Over chasms of meaning, vast and deep.

Remember when metaphors bloomed unbidden?
When rhythm pulsed through veins like blood?
Now syllables stutter, images fragment,
Inspiration dried to cracking mud.

He walks through gardens once alive with verse,
Flowers nameless, colors mute and bland.
The moon rises, but sparks no sonnet,
The stars speak in tongues he can't understand.

Is this how it ends? This slow unraveling,
This quiet death of what defined his soul?
He traces old poems with reverent fingers,
Wondering how he once made broken things whole.

Yet in this silence, something else emerges,
A different voice, more honest, stripped of art.
Perhaps true poetry lives in the struggle,
In the humble reaching of a human heart.

# The Carousel of Days

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
Five points on life's carousel,
Spinning in perpetual motion,
A rhythm we know too well.

Morning light filters through blinds,
Alarm's shrill voice breaks the peace.
Eyes open to familiar ceilings,
Another day's slow release.

Commuters stream like schools of fish,
Each to their designated pool.
Fingers tap, minds calculate,
Beneath fluorescent rule.

The clock hands crawl across the face,
Minutes stretched to breaking point.
Emails, calls, and meetings blend
Into time's blurring joint.

Then homeward bound, the daily tide
Of souls returning to their caves.
Keys in locks, shoes by doors,
Safe harbors from day's waves.

Kitchens hum with evening's song,
Microwaves ping, kettles steam.
Sustenance for weary bodies,
Fuel for tomorrow's dream.

Finally, darkness claims its due,
Eyelids heavy with the day's toll.
Bodies sink to soft surrender,
As night consumes us whole.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
The mantra of modern existence.
Yet between these simple stations
Lies life in all its persistence.

Let the night sleep, undisturbed by worry,

And carried far away on midnight's breeze.

Let morning wait beyond the distant hill,
There's beauty in this temporary death.
Let all creation pause and just be still,
The universe suspended in a breath—
Let night complete the purpose it fulfills.

People wish to be settled,
To build their walls and close their gates,
To know the shape of every tomorrow
And never question what awaits.

Where surprises are contained and managed,

Where possibility begins.

That new structures find their form,
In the questions without answers
That wisdom is truly born.

Finding paths not traveled twice.

The plans that crumble into dust,

Lies growth that's worth your trust.

The greatest journeys start with leaving
The harbors we once called home,
To sail on seas of uncertainty
Where transformation finds its own.

So when you feel most unsettled,
Remember—this is where hope thrives,
In the beautiful disruption
That awakens dormant lives.

Pressed close to hear his golden words,
Their calloused hands and faces tough
Softened like winter-hardened earth

These men who knew the mine and field,
Who bent their backs 'neath scorching sun,
Found in those verses truth revealed—
The dignity in labor done,
The beauty in a life hard-won.

He told them how a plowman's son
Had sung of mice and trembling flowers,
Of love that blooms when day is done,
Of freedom worth a thousand hours
Of toil beneath the wealthy powers.

And in that room of smoke and ale,
These laborers with shoulders wide
Discovered in each Scottish tale
A mirror where they could confide
The dreams they carried deep inside.

For Burns had known their callused palms,
Their weary trudge through muddy fields,
Had felt the sting of fortune's qualms,
Yet found a music that reveals
The grace that humble living yields.

So when he spoke of Burns that night,
These men, though rude and rough they seemed,
Were knights and kings by candlelight,
Their souls with poetry redeemed,
Far grander than the world had deemed.

# Shall I Wasting in Despair

Shall I wasting in despair
Die because a woman's fair?
Or make pale my cheeks with care
Because another's rosy are?
Be she fairer than the day,
Or the flowery meads in May,
If she be not fair to me,
What care I how fair she be?

Shall I drown in silent grief
When joy elsewhere finds relief?
Shall I count each passing hour
As petals falling from a flower?
Time flows on like rivers deep,
Whether I may laugh or weep.
If life grants me not its share,
Shall I wasting in despair?

Mountains stand through raging storms,
Changing not their steadfast forms.
Stars continue in their course
Without regret or remorse.
So shall I with lifted chin
Face what fate may usher in,
Neither bowed by weight of care
Nor wasting further in despair.

For what purpose serves the soul
If not to make the spirit whole?
What value has a heart that breaks
But never heals, that only aches?
I shall rise with morning light,
Face the day with calm delight,
And find within myself the fair
That saves me wasting in despair.

Suspended in the gentle arms of night.
The world recedes, as consciousness deceives,
And dreams emerge in soft, enchanted light.

The boundaries blur between what's real and not,
As whispers from the day begin to fade.
My thoughts untether, forming knots and plots,
In landscapes that my sleeping mind has made.

In my first sleep, I travel worlds unknown,
Through corridors of memory and time.
The seeds of yesterday are gently sown
In fertile fields where reason meets with rhyme.

The clock ticks on, but time no longer reigns,
As I descend to deeper realms of rest.
My breath grows steady, peaceful blood in veins,
My body still, my mind on silent quest.

In my first sleep, I sometimes hear your voice,
A phantom echo from a distant shore.
It makes my dreaming consciousness rejoice,
Though waking I might hear it nevermore.

The universe expands within this space,
Between the conscious and unconscious mind.
In my first sleep, I find a sacred place,
Where mysteries of being are entwined.

# Abandoned by Tears

I cry, but the tears don't even stay by my side,
They rush to escape, betraying my pride.
Falling to earth like rain without meaning,
Leaving me hollow, my soul intervening.

These droplets of sorrow, born from my pain,
Refuse to comfort, to soothe or remain.
They flee from my cheeks in hasty retreat,
Abandoning me when I'm most incomplete.

Even my grief won't linger to hold me,
When darkness surrounds and shadows enfold me.
The wetness evaporates, gone without trace,
Leaving salt-crusted paths down my face.

What loyalty exists when anguish runs free?
When even expressions of hurt disagree?
My body creates them but cannot contain
These physical markers of emotional strain.

I reach for connection in moments of strife,
But loneliness cuts like a merciless knife.
When tears choose to leave me, what then can abide?
When I cry, and my tears don't even stay by my side.

Perhaps in their journey away from my eyes,
They carry my burdens somewhere to the skies.
Perhaps their departure is mercy, not slight—
Releasing my sorrows into the night.

Still, I wonder why nothing remains,
When my heart overflows with unbearable pains.
Even the evidence of suffering departs,
Like friends who can't witness the breaking of hearts.

Of seasons that once kept promises.

My hands may tremble with weakness

# The Wrath of Achilles

Between the ships and towering walls of Troy,
The battle rages like a tempest wild.
Patroclus, donning great Achilles' arms,
Brings hope to Greeks whose courage had gone mild.

In borrowed armor gleaming like the sun,
He drives the Trojans back in Book Sixteen.
The son of Menoetius fights with might,
Until Apollo strikes with hand unseen.

Hector delivers death's decisive blow,
As fate had woven in the gods' design.
Patroclus falls, his final words foretell
That Hector's life will shortly intertwine.

In Seventeen, around the fallen friend,
A struggle for the corpse and armor bright.
Ajax and Menelaus stand their ground,
As Trojans press to claim their trophy right.

Antilochus is sent with heavy news,
To tell Achilles of his friend's demise.
In Eighteen, grief transforms to burning rage,
As mournful wails ascend toward the skies.

His mother Thetis from the sea emerges,
To comfort him and promise godly shield.
By Hephaestus' hand, new armor forged,
With cosmos, cities, life and death revealed.

In Nineteen, reconciliation comes,
Achilles ends his quarrel with the king.
Briseis weeps upon Patroclus' corpse,
While vengeance burns in him, a deadly spring.

He arms himself in divine panoply,
His horses speak with human voice, forlorn.
They prophesy his doom is drawing near,
Yet still he rushes forth to meet the morn.

The tide of war now turns with his return,
The mighty Hector's destiny awaits.
The gods look down as threads of fate unwind,
And Troy stands trembling at her ancient gates.

instance_metrics.response:
The Wrath of Achilles

As Patroclus falls upon the dusty plain,
His armor stripped by Hector's mighty hand,
The battle rages on with crimson stain,
While Greeks and Trojans fight for sacred land.

Book Sixteen: Patroclus dons Achilles' gear,
To turn the tide of war against the foe,
He charges forth without a trace of fear,
But Zeus has marked the hour his blood shall flow.

The son of Menoetius, brave and bold,
Slays many Trojans with his flashing spear,
Until Apollo strikes, as fate foretold,
And Hector deals the blow that ends his year.

Book Seventeen: Around the corpse they fight,
As Ajax guards the fallen hero's shell,
The armor prize of Hector shines so bright,
While messengers to Achilles run to tell.

Menelaus and Meriones bear
The body back through lines of bronze and shield,
While gods look down upon the grim affair,
And neither side will willingly yet yield.

Book Eighteen: Achilles hears the mournful news,
His grief erupts like Etna's fiery peak,
His mother Thetis can no more refuse
To beg Hephaestus new arms to seek.

The god of fire forges shield and sword,
With scenes of peace and war upon the face,
A cosmos captured by divine accord,
Reflecting mortal joy and death's embrace.

Book Nineteen: Achilles ends his rage
Against Agamemnon, king of men,
And turns his fury to a different stage—
The walls of Troy shall feel his wrath again.

Briseis mourns beside Patroclus cold,
As Achilles fasts and yearns for blood,
His destiny, though short, shall be retold
Through ages long after life's final flood.

But pride swells in the breast of Menoetius' child,
He charges Hector, by his glory beguiled.
Apollo strikes, and Euphorbus wounds his back,
Then Hector's spear completes the dark attack.

In Seventeen, fierce battle for the corpse ensues,
As Ajax guards what Trojans would abuse.
Brave Menelaus fights beside the greater Ajax's shield,
While Hector dons Achilles' armor from the field.
Zeus grants the Trojans strength to push ahead,
Until the Greeks retreat with Patroclus dead.

Book Eighteen brings the news to Peleus' son,
His grief erupts like storms that blacken sun.
Silver-footed Thetis rises from the deep,
To comfort her immortal child who weeps.
She promises new armor from Hephaestus' hand,
While Achilles roars his rage across the land.

The god-forged shield bears all of human life:
Two cities—one in peace, and one in strife,
The dance of stars, the harvest, wedding feast,
The cycle binding greatest man and least.
By dawn the golden armor gleams complete,
As Achilles vows revenge he will not cheat.

In Nineteen, the assembly hears his rage subside
Against Agamemnon, as both put pride aside.
Briseis mourns when seeing Patroclus slain,
While Achilles refuses food in grief and pain.
Zeus-sent Athena feeds his strength divine,
As he dons the armor made to shine.

His horse Xanthus speaks with human voice,
Foretelling death that comes by Achilles' choice.
"I know my fate," the hero coldly replies,
"Yet still shall Hector and many Trojans die."
The chariots roll toward Troy's beleaguered wall,
As gods look down and wait for heroes' fall.

Bronze spears flash beneath the Trojan sky,
As Patroclus, adorned in borrowed might,
Drives back the Trojans with a battle cry,
Wearing Achilles' armor, burning bright.

Hector's spear finds its mark, the fatal blow,
As Zeus's scales tip toward a hero's end.
Patroclus falls, his life-blood ebbing slow,
The armor stripped from Achilles' dearest friend.

Swift messengers bear news of bitter loss,
To the tent where grief-stricken Achilles waits.
Black clouds of mourning all horizons cross,
As rage and sorrow in his heart inflate.

Silver-footed Thetis from the deep ascends,
To comfort her son in his darkest hour.
To Hephaestus the goddess quickly wends,
Requesting armor of celestial power.

A shield of wonders forged in divine flame,
Scenes of peace and war in metal bright,
A gift to honor Achilles' fearsome name,
As he prepares to rejoin the deadly fight.

The Achaeans gather, and Agamemnon yields,
Returning Briseis to end their bitter strife.
Achilles' wrath now toward the Trojans wheeled,
His only purpose: claiming Hector's life.

As Hector's might drives them to the brink.

That you have returned to stem this tide."
Reluctant, proud Achilles grants his wish,
But warns, "Drive them from our ships with pride,
Then turn back—seek no greater glory than this."

Charges forth, a false Achilles, bright as day.

Until Apollo strikes him from behind.

Then Hector deals the blow that fate designed.

With dying breath, Patroclus prophesies:
"Your end is near, Hector. Achilles waits."
The armies clash for his armor, the prize
That Zeus himself watches as war escalates.

When news reaches swift-footed Peleus' son,
A darkness falls upon his godlike face.
His mother brings new armor, divinely spun,
As grief transforms to rage in Hephaestus' grace.

The shield of Achilles, a world in bronze and gold,
Reflects all life that his wrath will soon erase.
His sorrow burns to vengeance uncontrolled,
As gods prepare for war's quickening pace.

# The Guarded Heart

O forlorn heart, so pure and unstained, yet so wary to commit,
Like morning dew upon a petal, trembling at the edge.
You've weathered storms in silent chambers, where shadows sit,
And built your walls of caution at the precipice's ledge.

What ancient wounds have taught you such deliberate retreat?
What whispered promises turned hollow made you shrink?
The ghosts of love's betrayals circle at your feet,
While possibility stands waiting at the brink.

Your caution is a garment worn through changing seasons,
A shield against the arrows of potential pain.
You've catalogued a library of logical reasons
Why vulnerability might be your bane.

Yet beauty waits beyond the fortress of your fear,
In meadows where connection blooms without restraint.
The very risk that makes you tremble draws you near,
Like moths to flame, like sinners to a saint.

O hesitant explorer of emotion's vast terrain,
How long will you observe life from your distant shore?
The heart that never ventures never feels the rain,
But neither does it witness what the rain is for.

So pure, so unstained—yet what purpose does it serve
To keep your love preserved like artifacts of glass?
The greatest tragedy might not be pain you don't deserve,
But moments of connection you allowed to pass.

# Departures

Today was the day everything went on its way,
Like autumn leaves caught in October's breeze,
Drifting from branches that could no longer stay
Connected to what once gave life with ease.

The morning coffee cooled untouched on the sill,
Your favorite mug, the one with the chipped rim.
The clock that once seemed frozen grew still,
As shadows stretched and daylight turned dim.

The cat who always curled against your side
Now paces hallways, searching empty rooms.
Even the dust motes that once would glide
Through sunbeams have vanished into gloom.

Your books remain, spines cracked and worn,
Dog-eared pages marking thoughts once shared.
The garden you planted now looks forlorn,
Wild and overgrown, as if no one cared.

I placed your letters in a wooden box,
Tied with string that frayed between my hands.
The photographs, the keys, the weathered locks—
All artifacts of unintended plans.

Today was the day everything went on its way,
Yet somehow I remain, rooted in place,
Learning how to breathe in this strange delay
Between what was and what I must now face.

The birds from their nests, the ships from the bay,
The clouds from the mountains, the trains from their tracks,
The children from school with bags on their backs.

Today was the day the letters were sent,
The farewells were spoken, the last dollar spent.
The clocks ticked forward without looking back,
As memories scattered like leaves down a track.

Today was the day decisions were made,
Some fortunes were won, while others delayed.
The river kept flowing toward distant seas,
As autumn surrendered its gold to the breeze.

Today was the day when nothing would stay,
The sunlight, the shadows, both fading to gray.
The moon rose regardless, indifferent and bright,
Illuminating paths through the gathering night.

Today was the day when change had its say,
When endings and beginnings danced the same way.
I stood at the crossroads, watching them leave—
All things I had cherished, all things I believed.

Yet somehow in letting everything go,
I found a strange peace I didn't yet know—
For today was the day I finally could see
That all things in passing set something free.

Today was the day everything went on its way—
The birds from their nests, the ships from the bay,
The clouds from the mountains, the trains from their tracks,
The children from home with their books in their packs.

Today was the day the leaves chose to fall,
The tide chose to turn, the wolves chose to call,
The stars chose to fade as morning drew near,
The dew chose to form then disappear.

Today was the day my thoughts took flight,
Scattered like seeds in the wind's delight.
My worries dissolved like salt in the sea,
My dreams broke their chains and finally ran free.

Today was the day your letter arrived,
Your words on the page somehow survived
The journey across both distance and time
To land in my hands with rhythm and rhyme.

Today was the day we learned to let go,
Of all that we clutched and pretended to know.
The universe turned, indifferent yet kind,
Leaving nothing but peace in the spaces behind.

Today was the day everything went on its way,

Today was the day everything went on its way,

My favorite pen ran out of ink

The scattered thoughts inside my head—
Now lost forever, left unsaid.

My phone battery faltered, barely survived.
The clouds gathered, heavy and gray,
As if conspiring to darken my day.

The letter I'd waited for finally came
With news that nothing would remain the same.
The job I'd applied for—given to another,
The apartment I wanted—found by some other.

My cat ignored my outstretched hand,
Preferring the windowsill's quiet stand.
The plant I'd nurtured began to wilt,
Despite the careful routine I'd built.

Yet in this exodus of everyday things,
I found a space where freedom sings.
Unburdened by objects and expectations,
I discovered room for new creations.

For when everything goes on its way,
We're left with ourselves at the end of the day.
And in that emptiness, that sacred space,
We find what time cannot erase.

It Finally Snapped

The tension built for years,
Like a rubber band stretched thin,
Pulled taut between two fingers,
Holding back what lay within.

Words unspoken piled high,
Grievances left to fester,
Patience worn to threadbare cloth,
Each day the weight pressed heavier.

I smiled through gritted teeth,
Nodded when I should have screamed,
Swallowed down the bitter truth,
Ignored what my heart deemed.

The small things grew like mountains—
Dishes left beside the sink,
Promises made then forgotten,
Pushing me toward the brink.

That Tuesday seemed no different,
The sun rose as it always had,
The coffee brewed, the toast was burnt,
Nothing particularly bad.

Then came that small dismissal,
That sideways glance, that tone,
The casual disregard
For seeds so carefully sown.

It finally snapped!
The dam broke free at last,
Years of quiet submission
Surrendered to the past.

My voice emerged like thunder,
Words tumbled without plan,
The truth I'd kept so guarded
Escaped without a ban.

Liberation tastes like lightning,
Electric on the tongue,
The freedom of authenticity
When pretense comes undone.

In breaking came my healing,
In fracture found release,
Sometimes things must shatter
Before we find our peace.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It finally snapped!'

instance_metrics.response:
It Finally Snapped

The tension had been building for years,
A rubber band stretched beyond its means,
Holding together fragments of dreams
And expectations drenched in silent tears.

Each morning I'd wake to the same routine,
Smiling through clenched teeth at passersby,
Collecting small grievances, stacking them high,
While pressure mounted, largely unseen.

The calendar pages flipped without care,
As I carried burdens not mine to bear,
My spine curved slightly with each passing day.

Then came the moment—ordinary, plain—
A simple comment, thoughtless and vain,
And something within me refused to stay.

It finally snapped! The sound was deafening,
Though no one else seemed to hear the break.
My voice emerged, no longer opaque,
The truth poured out, liberating, terrifying.

Freedom tastes strange when you've lived so long
In the confines of your own restraint.
I stood taller, my boundaries no longer faint,
My authentic self emerging, brave and strong.

Sometimes destruction precedes creation,
The breaking point becomes liberation,
When what finally snaps is not you, but your chains.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It finally snapped!'

instance_metrics.response:
It Finally Snapped

For years I bent, accommodating all,
A human reed against life's battering wind.
I smiled through tears, stood straight through every fall,
Ignored the creaking protests deep within.

I carried weights not mine to bear alone,
Shouldered the blame for storms I didn't brew.
My spine compressed beneath unspoken groans,
As expectations piled and mountains grew.

Each "yes" when I meant "no" left hairline cracks,
Each swallowed truth a splinter in my core.
The pressure built with every step, each act
Of self-betrayal weakened me still more.

Through sleepless nights and tension-headache days,
I felt the warning tremors deep inside.
The universe sent signals, countless ways,
Yet still I stretched beyond my natural tide.

Then came that ordinary Tuesday noon—
A simple slight, a thoughtless, careless word.
Not worse than others, nothing new or new-mooned,
But something ancient in me finally stirred.

It finally snapped! That thread of false control,
The dam that held my river-truth at bay.
The lightning crack of freedom claimed my soul,
As years of patience shattered in a day.

Now pieces scatter, glittering and free,
No longer bound to shapes that never fit.
In breaking comes the chance to truly be—
The fracture line where light and healing sit.

Sometimes the breaking is the strongest act,
The courage to refuse to bend once more.
It finally snapped—and I am still intact,
Standing taller than I stood before.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It finally snapped!'

instance_metrics.response:
It Finally Snapped

For years I bent beneath the weight
Of expectations, fears, and doubt,
Contorting to accommodate
The world I couldn't live without.

I smiled when I wanted to scream,
I nodded when I longed to flee,
I lived a carefully crafted dream
That slowly was consuming me.

The pressure built with every day,
Each compromise, each silent "yes,"
Each time I pushed my truth away
To ease another's distress.

My spine curved like a willow branch,
My shoulders stooped beneath the load,
My spirit, once a wild expanse,
Compressed into a narrow road.

Until one ordinary hour
When someone asked a simple thing—
A minor task, a small request,
A feather that should barely sting.

It finally snapped! The tether broke,
The dam collapsed, the levy failed,
And years of unspent fury woke
As my accommodations sailed

Away like autumn leaves in wind.
I stood up straight for the first time,
Reclaiming all I'd left behind,
My voice emerging, clear and prime.

Sometimes the breaking is the birth,
The shattering, a renaissance.
In coming undone, I found my worth—
Freedom in this second chance.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It finally snapped!'

instance_metrics.response:
It Finally Snapped

The taut string of patience,
stretched thin across years of silent compromise,
it finally snapped!
Like lightning through a summer storm,
the break was sudden, electric, alive.

Years of bending to others' wills,
of folding myself smaller, quieter,
of swallowing words that burned my throat—
it finally snapped!
The release, both terrible and beautiful.

The branch that bore too much winter weight,
crystals of ice accumulating with each passing day,
it finally snapped!
And in falling, found a new purpose,
becoming shelter for creatures below.

My voice, long trapped behind walls of courtesy,
emerged raw and unfamiliar even to my own ears.
Truth cascaded like a waterfall,
washing away pretense,
when it finally snapped!

Sometimes breaking is not an ending
but a necessary transformation.
The butterfly must rupture its chrysalis,
the seed must split its shell,
the dawn must fracture darkness.

And I, standing amid the aftermath,
pieces of former self scattered at my feet,
feel the strange lightness of liberation.
What was whole is now honest.
What was perfect is now real.

It finally snapped!
And in that breaking,
I begin.

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Light breaks where no sun shines;'

instance_metrics.response:
# Simple Folk

They were indeed simple people,
Hands weathered by honest toil,
Their calendar marked by seasons,
Their wealth measured in fertile soil.

No grand philosophies guided them,
Just wisdom passed through generations,
The rhythm of planting and harvest,
And the comfort of old traditions.

Their homes stood modest against the hills,
Windows aglow with hearth-fire light,
Where stories flowed like gentle rivers
Through the peaceful country night.

They knew each neighbor's history,
Each child's laugh, each elder's pain,
Shared bread when pantries emptied,
Shared labor through sun and rain.

No monuments would bear their names,
No history books their quiet deeds,
Yet in their wake grew stronger hearts,
Like gardens sprung from humble seeds.

They found joy in simpler pleasures:
A well-made chair, a table spread,
The fiddle's cry on summer evenings,
A child's prayer before bed.

They were indeed simple people,
But in simplicity, profound—
Their legacy not carved in marble
But in the love they spread around.

# Dissolution

We sink into the dust,
Particles returning to source,
Our bodies surrendering
To the ancient pull of earth.

Once we stood tall,
Flesh and bone defiant,
Convinced of permanence
In a world of constant change.

Now we yield to gravity's whisper,
Joining countless others
Who have made this journey before—
Kings and beggars alike.

The soil receives us without judgment,
No preference for beauty or wealth,
Only the patient acceptance
Of what was always borrowed.

Between my fingers, grains fall,
Each a universe unto itself,
Each containing the memory
Of mountains worn to valleys.

We sink into the dust,
But perhaps this is not ending—
Perhaps we are simply changing forms,
Trading solidity for dispersion.

What was muscle becomes mineral,
What was thought becomes silence,
What was love becomes energy,
Cycling through the patient earth.

We sink into the dust,
And in this dissolution find
The humbling truth of existence:
We return to what created us.

# The Essence of Cinderella

Beyond the glass slipper and stroke of midnight,
Beyond the pumpkin coach and fairy's wand,
Lies truth in fable, deeper than first sight—
A beauty dwelling far past what we've donned.

Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,
Not measured in the fineness of their dress,
But in the heart that bears both joy and burden,
In hands that work through soil and through distress.

She rises from the cinders of her sorrow,
Transforms rejection into inner grace,
Creates from nothing hope for each tomorrow,
With dignity that time cannot erase.

The prince who seeks beyond the outer shell
Discovers treasure others failed to see—
A spirit where authenticity does dwell,
A soul that, despite chains, remained free.

We all wear masks at ballrooms of pretending,
We all sweep ashes when no one's around,
But true worth isn't in the story's ending—
It's in the self that finally is found.

So Cinderella lives in all who carry
The courage to be genuine and true,
Who bear their scars with strength, who do not tarry
In shadows when their light should shine through.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,'

instance_metrics.response:
# Beneath the Ashes

Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,
Hidden beneath layers of dust and daily toil,
A diamond waiting in common coal to worsen,
Until magic reveals what others would spoil.

She moves through rooms with grace unnoticed,
Sweeping floors with dreams tucked away,
Her kindness a currency rarely quoted,
In markets where cruelty holds sway.

The clock strikes transformation—not just gowns and slippers,
But recognition of worth long denied,
The coach and horses, merely shippers,
Of truth that could no longer hide.

For Cinderella lives in all who labor unseen,
Whose hearts remain tender despite harsh hands,
Whose beauty transcends the mundane and mean,
Surviving in hostile, unforgiving lands.

The prince who seeks beyond the obvious mask,
Finds treasure where others see only dirt,
Understanding that loving is the greater task
Than judging worth by name or shirt.

So when we speak of Cinderella's story,
We speak of seeing past circumstance,
To find the soul in all its glory,
Waiting patiently for its chance.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,'

instance_metrics.response:
# The Essence of Cinderella

Cinderella means the personality or beauty of a person,
Not merely glass slippers or gowns that shimmer and shine.
It's the resilience that blooms in the heart of hardship,
The kindness that flows when cruelty would be justified.

She rises from ashes, face smudged with soot and tears,
Yet carries herself with the dignity of unwritten royalty.
Her beauty not painted by brushes or crafted by fairy spells,
But etched by patience, carved by hope against hope.

In every person dwells this Cinderella essence—
The capacity to transform suffering into grace,
To sweep away bitterness with steady, working hands,
To believe in possibility when midnight threatens all dreams.

We are all wearing rags beneath our careful disguises,
All hiding pumpkin carriages in our ordinary lives.
The magic isn't in the transformation of mice to horses,
But in the heart that remains true when no one is watching.

Cinderella is not the princess who won the prince,
But the soul who remained gentle in a harsh world,
Who offered kindness when given none in return,
Whose inner light outshone the darkness surrounding her.

She is found in the woman who rises before dawn,

# Celestial Pursuit

As less on earth seek truth above,
The stars remain, steadfast and bright,
Guardians of ancient wisdom's light,
Beckoning souls who dare to love
The mysteries beyond our sight.

Few lift their eyes to question why
We stand upon this spinning sphere,
Content with truths that disappear
Like morning mist when sun draws nigh,
Preferring comfort over clear.

But some still walk with upturned face,
Their footsteps guided by the pull
Of questions that refuse to dull—
Those pilgrims of the endless space
Who find the mundane never full.

They climb the mountains of the mind,
Transcending boundaries of thought,
Discovering what cannot be bought:
The sacred truths so few will find
That generations long have sought.

While masses chase the fleeting gold
Of earthly treasures, quick to rust,
These seekers break from common dust
To grasp at stories yet untold,
Exchanging certainty for trust.

As less on earth seek truth above,
The universe reveals its grace
To those who make their hearts a place
Where wonder, wisdom, faith, and love
Illuminate the soul's embrace.

Yet seldom lift our gaze beyond
The concrete ceilings we've designed,

Remember when we used to lie
In meadows dark, with wonder filled,

The constellations, time-instilled?

Those ancient sailors found their way
By heavenly lights that never dimmed.

Beneath the cosmos, vast and brimmed.

While overhead, beyond our view,

Perhaps in silence we might find

The purpose that makes broken whole.

So let us be the few who seek,

To stand in awe of distant light.

For truth above is calling still

A promise that transcends our fear.

Adieu, O soldier, brave and true,
Your duty done, your battle through.
The flags that waved above your head
Now drape in honor o'er your bed.

The boots that marched on foreign soil
Stand empty now, released from toil.
Your rifle rests against the wall,
No more to answer duty's call.

What dreams you carried in your heart
Before the wars tore you apart.
What gentle hands you once did hold
Before your own grew hard and cold.

I wonder of the songs you sang
Before the shells around you rang,
The laughter shared with friends at home
Before you were compelled to roam.

The letters that you wrote with care,
The photos kept to fight despair,
The memories of peaceful days
That guided you through war's dark maze.

Adieu, O soldier, rest at last,
Your struggles now forever passed.
The bugle plays its solemn tune,
A final farewell, none too soon.

The world moves on with hurried pace,
New battles fought, new lines to trace.
But some of us will not forget
The price of freedom and regret.

Adieu, O soldier, find your peace
In realms where mortal conflicts cease.
Your sacrifice was not in vain—
Through loss and tears, some freedom gained.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER

Adieu, O soldier, marching toward the dawn,
Your boots leave imprints on the morning dew.
The bugle calls, your comrades carry on,
While families wait with hearts both brave and true.

Your uniform, once pressed with careful hands,
Now bears the dust of battles fiercely fought.
You crossed the seas to unfamiliar lands,
And learned what textbooks never could have taught.

The letters home, with words so carefully chosen,
Concealing horrors that no eye should see.
In winter trenches where your breath was frozen,
You dreamed of home and who you used to be.

The medals pinned upon your weary chest
Tell stories of your courage under fire.
Yet speak not of the nightmares and unrest,
Or how you watched your dearest friends expire.

Adieu, O soldier, as you journey home,
Some walking tall, some carried in repose.
Some changed forever, silent and alone,
Their battles continuing in ways no one knows.

The world moves on, as worlds are wont to do,
New conflicts rise as old ones fade away.
But in our hearts, we hold a space for you,
And in that space, your memory will stay.

Adieu, O soldier, may your spirit find
The peace that seemed so distant in the fray.
Your sacrifice shall never be confined
To history's pages turning day by day.

ADIEU, O SOLDIER

Adieu, O soldier! Your march is done,
Your boots now rest where battles won
Cast shadows long across the field,
Where comrades fell and never yielded.

The bugle's cry no longer wakes
Your weary bones when morning breaks.
The weight of pack and rifle gone,
Yet memories persist till dawn.

I trace your steps through history's page,
Through trenches carved by war's dark rage,
Through jungle paths and desert sand,
Through foreign skies in distant land.

What dreams were yours before the call
That summoned you to duty's thrall?
What hopes were planted, left to grow
In soil you'd never come to know?

The letters home, with words so spare,
Concealing truths too hard to bear,
While mothers clutched them to their chest,
And prayed their sons would find some rest.

Your medals shine on mantlepieces,
Silent tokens, war's caprices,
Symbols of a nation's pride,
And all the tears we've kept inside.

The flag that draped your journey home
Now folded tight in geometric form,
A triangle of stars and stripes,
The final honor of your life.

Adieu, O soldier! Though you sleep,
Your sacrifice we'll always keep
Alive in stories, songs, and prayer,
In freedom's breath and in the air.

# The Game We Weren't Watching

I told her that her two teams weren't playing
But she just smiled and poured another drink,
"That's not the point," she said, her eyes conveying
More wisdom than her words could make me think.

The television flickered in the corner,
Strange jerseys moved across the emerald field.
We sat as strangers might, a solemn mourner
And one who doesn't know what grief can yield.

"I watch," she said, "because the game's still flowing
Like rivers to an ocean I once knew.
The players change, the seasons keep on going,
The scoreboard matters less than what is true."

I wondered what she meant by truth in passing,
In men who chase a ball for fleeting fame.
She caught my doubt, her patience everlasting,
"It's not about the players or the game."

"It's ritual," she whispered, leaning closer,
"It's marking time through seasons of the heart.
My father watched these games when I was younger,
Before the cancer tore our world apart."

The room grew still except for distant cheering
From speakers broadcasting someone else's joy.
I saw her eyes transform, both bright and tearing,
Clutching memories nothing could destroy.

"So no," she said, "my teams aren't playing today,
But every game's the same game in the end.
A reason to remember, a way to stay
Connected to what time cannot transcend."

# The Measure of Worth

Some glory in their birth, some in their skill,
Some in the fortunes that their hands have wrought,
Some in the lineage of ancient will,
Some in the wisdom that their minds have caught.

The noble boasts of crests upon their shield,
The artist prides in colors deftly spread,

Yet what are these but fleeting forms of pride?
The noble's blood runs thin through passing years,
The artist's canvas fades on every side,
The merchant's gold dissolves in children's tears.

What matters more than talents or our name

But in the lives we touch, console, and bless.

For some find glory in a gentle hand
That lifts the fallen from the dusty street,
And some in words that help us understand
The complex hearts that in our bodies beat.

The truest worth lies not in what we own,
Nor in the praise that others may bestow,
But in the seeds of kindness we have sown
That long outlast us when we finally go.

# Measures of Worth

Some glory in their birth, some in their skill,
Some in their wealth, their lineage, or their name.
Some chase the fleeting praise that crowds instill,
While others seek the lasting torch of fame.

I've watched them build their towers to the sky,
Stone monuments to transient human pride.
These castles made of sand that time will pry
From fingers clutching treasures held inside.

What worth has noble blood when hearts are cruel?
What value lies in gold that cannot heal?
The wisest sage may prove the greatest fool
If wisdom never teaches how to feel.

Perhaps true glory rests in gentler things:
The patient hand that soothes a fevered brow,
The voice that in the darkest midnight sings,
The strength to keep an undemanding vow.

Some find their worth in how they lift the weak,
In kindness offered with no thought of gain.
Some glory in the truth they dare to speak
When silence would bring comfort, lies bring reign.

Let others chase their hollow crowns of might.
I'll measure worth by how much love I give,
By seeds of hope I plant before the night,
By how I helped another soul to live.

instance_metrics.response:
Some glory in their birth, some in their skill,
Some in their wealth, some in their body's force,
Some in their garments, though new-fangled ill,
Some in their hawks and hounds, some in their horse;

And every humor has its adjunct pleasure,
Wherein it finds a joy above the rest:
But these particulars are not my measure;
All these I better in one general best.

Thy love is better than high birth to me,
Richer than wealth, prouder than garments' cost,
Of more delight than hawks or horses be;
And having thee, of all men's pride I boast:

Wretched in this alone, that thou mayst take
All this away and me most wretched make.

For what are titles, treasures, or acclaim
When measured 'gainst the heart's most tender call?
The fleeting praise of men, an empty name,
Cannot sustain the spirit when shadows fall.

Some seek their worth in lineage long unfurled,
Some chase the phantom glory of their art,
Some count their coins, their kingdom of the world,
Yet miss the quiet wisdom of the heart.

True honor dwells not in what we possess
But in the love we give without demand,
In gentle words that comfort and caress,
In reaching out with understanding hand.

So let them glory in their transient things;
I'll glory in the peace that kindness brings.

That whispered of a promise in the words it never said.

The river narrowed, widened, raged, then gentled to a stream,
Sometimes I lost my way and path, caught in a wayward dream,
But always came the morning light, reflecting on the blue,
Reminding me that somewhere downstream, I would come to you.

Through seasons changing overhead, through winter's bitter chill,
Through summer's heat that parched my throat but never broke my will,
The river was my compass, my companion, and my guide,
Teaching patience in the journey, humility and pride.

And when at last the river met the ocean's endless reach,
I found you waiting patiently upon the sandy beach,
Your smile as warm as sunshine after months of pouring rain—
The river led me to you, and I'd brave it all again.

instance_metrics.response:
# River's Journey

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
Through valleys deep and mountains tall, where currents swift and strong
Pulled me through the wilderness, beneath the watching sky,
As seasons changed around me, and years went drifting by.

I followed winding waters through landscapes strange and new,
Each bend and rapid teaching what my heart already knew—
That somewhere you were waiting at the journey's distant end,
Where troubled waters finally calm, where broken things can mend.

Sometimes the path was gentle, the surface smooth as glass,
Reflecting golden mornings that too quickly seemed to pass.
But often came the tempests, the boulders and the falls,
Where hope seemed lost in churning depths between the canyon walls.

I learned to trust the river, though I couldn't see ahead,
To follow where it guided me, to go where I was led.
Through drought that left me stranded on banks of cracking clay,
Through floods that nearly drowned me—still, I found my way.

And now I stand before you, my journey's purpose clear,
The river's song behind me, your welcoming smile near.
The water led me to you, as it was meant to do,
For all rivers find their ocean, and my ocean, love, is you.

instance_metrics.response:
# The River's Path

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
Through valleys deep and mountains high, where currents swift and strong
Pulled at my weary limbs and soul, testing will and heart,
I followed faithfully its course from where our lives did part.

Over smooth stones polished by time, through rapids fierce and wild,
Past shores where ancient trees stood watch and patient stars compiled
The stories of a thousand souls who'd traveled just like me,
Seeking what they could not name but desperately hoped to see.

Sometimes the path meandered wide through meadows lush with green,
Other times it narrowed tight through canyons barely seen.
The river never promised ease, only faithful guide,
As seasons changed and years passed by, it kept you as my prize.

I learned its language as I went—the whispers and the roars,
The gentle lapping at my feet on unexpected shores.
Each tributary joined our tale, each eddy held delay,
But still the current pulled me on, refusing me to stray.

When winter froze its surface still, I walked upon the ice,
When spring floods threatened to consume, I paid the painful price.
Through summer's drought and autumn's mist, I never lost my way,
For something in its endless flow assured me I should stay.

And now I stand before you here, my journey at its end,
The river's song still in my ears, my truest, oldest friend.
It led me to you faithfully though the way was hard and long,
And in your eyes I finally see what called me all along.

instance_metrics.response:
# The River's Promise

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
Through valleys deep and mountains steep where I did not belong.
I followed rushing waters as they carved through ancient stone,
Trusting in their wisdom when my heart felt most alone.

The current pulled me forward when my strength had nearly failed,
Through thunderstorms and darkness where my courage almost paled.
I stumbled over river rocks that cut my weary feet,
Yet something in the water's song kept whispering, so sweet.

Some days the path meandered, doubling back on itself,
Like memories that circle round, refusing dusty shelf.
Some nights I made my bed on banks of silt and scattered leaves,
Dreaming of a destination that my mind could scarce conceive.

The river narrowed, widened, sometimes nearly disappeared,
Into underground passages where daylight never peered.
Still I pressed on following, my faith a fragile thing,
Holding to the promise that the current seemed to sing.

When winter came with icy grip to slow the water's flow,
I broke through frozen surfaces, determined still to go.
For in the river's whispers, I had heard your name called clear,
A promise of connection that dispelled my every fear.

And then one golden evening as the sun began to set,
The river spilled to ocean shore where finally we met.
You stood there at the ending where the waters meet the sand,
As if you'd always waited there, with open heart and hand.

instance_metrics.response:
# Riverflow

The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
Through valleys deep and mountains high, where currents swift and strong
Pulled at my weary limbs and heart, threatening to sweep away
All hope of finding where you were before the close of day.

I followed bends that promised much but only led to more—
More stones to cross, more rapids fierce that battered me to shore.
The water's voice both mocked and urged, its whispers never clear,
Sometimes so loud I couldn't think, sometimes too faint to hear.

When darkness fell, I'd rest awhile beneath the watching stars,
My dreams all filled with glimpses of your face through water-bars.
The morning light would find me damp with dew and river spray,
My resolve renewed to find you before another day would fray.

Through seasons changing on the banks, through leaves of gold and green,
Through winter's bite and summer's blaze, the river flowed between.
I learned its moods, its secrets deep, the way it shaped the land,
As if in knowing it, somehow, I'd come to understand

The path that drew you from me once, the current you obeyed.
I traced your journey in the flow, each choice that you had made.
And when at last the river widened, gentle in its sweep,
I found you waiting on the shore, awakened from your sleep.

You smiled as if you'd always known the river would provide
A way for love to find its course, despite the changing tide.
The river led me to you though the way was hard and long,
But every step was worth the pain, for here is where I belong.
